headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt for the week of March 7 - 12, 2011.

headline: What's Hot…and Not
summary: A graphical look at how different investments, from REIT shares to crude oil, fared last week.

headline: Clocks Move Forward
summary: Most U.S. and Canada switch to daylight-saving time at 2 a.m. Sunday. Clocks move forward by one hour. Standard time returns Nov. 6.

headline: Treasury to Sell $62 Billion in Securities
summary: The Treasury plans to sell $62 billion Monday in short-term bills.

headline: Nokia Pays Elop More Than $6 Million to Join
summary: Nokia will pay new Chief Executive Stephen Elop a more than $6 million signing bonus for joining the world's largest handset maker, according to documents filed Friday.

headline: Quake, Tsunami Spur Japan Bears to Action
summary: Though the U.S. stock market held up well, Japan's earthquake and tsunami spurred bearish U.S. options trading on a number of companies and exchange-traded funds with exposure to the country.

headline: Fidelity Income Rises 17%
summary: Fidelity Investments' operating income jumped 17% in 2010 during a year when capital markets rebounded.

headline: Jerry Brown Is Dogging It
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAIL  The California governor sends the First Dog to do a man's job.

headline: Triangle Fire: Tracing a Tragedy
summary: The Triangle Shirtwaist Co. fire claimed the lives of 146 workers on March 25, 1911. A look at the fatal fire, a city's anguish and the modern aftermath of the tragedy.

headline: Stocks Push Higher
summary: The Dow industrials rose 0.5% to 12044.40 despite a major earthquake in Japan. 3M and Caterpillar led gains as investors bet that the companies might benefit from rebuilding efforts. But the market posted a weekly drop.

headline: Waves Slam California Harbor
summary: The quake's U.S. repercussions were felt first in Hawaii, but the worst damage on the U.S. mainland appeared to be in the Crescent City Harbor, near the Oregon border, where 35 boats and most docks were destroyed.

headline: Chevron to Sell Refinery to Valero
summary: Chevron agreed to sell a U.K. refinery and other assets to Valero for $730 million. Valero also will pay about $1 billion for inventory and other items.

headline: Google to Help Broker Video Ads
summary: Google is creating a video marketplace that matches advertisers with website publishers, including Google's own YouTube site.

headline: Noonan: The Defense Secretary Who Let Bin Laden Get Away
summary: Memoirist Rumsfeld seems to forget why we went to Afghanistan.

headline: Sahara Hotel in Las Vegas Closes Amid Losses
summary: The Sahara Hotel and Casino will be shuttered, marking a milestone in Las Vegas's ongoing recession as the first casino on the once-booming Las Vegas Strip to close during the recent downturn.

headline: Quake, Tsunami Throw More Uncertainty Onto U.S. Stocks
summary: The uncertain impact of Japan's powerful earthquake injects more worry into the U.S. markets at a time when investors are already pondering a number of trouble spots around the globe.

headline: Reinsurer Stocks Take Hit
summary: Reinsurers saw their stocks fall as investors fretted over possibly hefty claims stemming from the Japan quake, but executives are hopeful the impact will be limited.

headline: GOP Leader Makes Opening Bid on Debt Ceiling
summary: Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell, in an interview with The Wall Street Journal, said no Republican senator would vote to raise the federal debt ceiling unless Obama stepped in and helped craft a broad deficit-reduction deal.

headline: Florida's Rail Funds Up for Grabs
summary: The Obama administration launched a monthlong process to determine which states will receive $2.4 billion to upgrade and construct passenger-rail lines, after Florida rejected the funds last month.

headline: U.S. Probes Bahraini Security Forces
summary: The Obama administration has launched an investigation into the role of Bahraini security forces in violent crackdowns on protesters, part of a broader reassessment of U.S. security assistance and big-ticket arms sales to long-time Arab allies caught up in a wave of popular revolts.

headline: Quake Warning System Alerted Tokyo
summary: Some people in Tokyo were warned that a major earthquake was about to hit by an early warning system, the world's first, which was developed by the country's meteorological agency.

headline: Tsunami Prompts Evacuations
summary: People around the Pacific rim sought higher ground after a deadly earthquake struck Japan, triggering a tsunami.

headline: Manchin's Rebellion
summary: A Democratic senator attacks the Obama budget.

headline: Gold Edges Higher
summary: Gold futures rose modestly as investors mulled the consequences of a major earthquake that hit Japan.

headline: VF Focuses on Outdoor, Action Segment
summary: Apparel giant VF is ramping up its emphasis on outdoor and action sports as it bets on its higher-margin businesses for growth.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, customers wait to purchase Apple's iPad 2, a volcano spews smoke in Indonesia, Libyan rebels suffer casualties and more.

headline: Sheen Plans Live Stage Performances
summary: With Charlie Sheen's primetime television career in question, the embattled actor is taking it to the stage. He has scheduled live shows at theaters in Detroit and Chicago.

headline: Crude Ends Lower
summary: Crude futures settled around $101 a barrel on the Nymex amid expectations that demand would drop after an earthquake in Japan, the world's third-largest oil consumer.

headline: Quake Adds to Stock Woes in Asia, Europe
summary: European stocks opened lower, as a large earthquake in Japan triggered a selloff in European reinsurers, and declines in the U.S. and Asia equity markets and higher-than-expected Chinese inflation data weighed on sentiment.

headline: AnnTaylor Posts Higher Profit
summary: AnnTaylor Stores reported much-improved quarterly results and said it will change its corporate name to Ann Inc.

headline: West Coast Refiners Report No Impact
summary: The West Coast's largest oil refiners weren't affected by the tsunami resulting from a major earthquake in Japan, but they are closely watching the situation.

headline: Fuel Costs Surge
summary: The cost of natural gas and other fuels soared on expectations that Japan would turn to these fuels while its nuclear power plants are offline.

headline: Star Scientific's Patents Confirmed
summary: Star Scientific said the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office confirmed the validity of the company's patents that are at the center of lawsuits filed against Reynolds American.

headline: Japan Refineries Close
summary: The earthquake that struck Japan has shut down some of the country's biggest refineries, potentially unsettling global oil and fuel markets if the plants took major damage.

headline: From Kobe to Katrina, Disasters Have Little Sway on Stocks
summary: Wall Street has a history of shrugging off major earthquakes and other natural disasters, and so far this time isn't proving any different.

headline: Strong Earthquake Strikes Japan
summary: A powerful earthquake with a magnitude of 8.9 struck Japan Friday afternoon, causing damage in Tokyo and many injuries in the north where the quake was centered, and sending a tsunami hurtling across the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Irish Banks Still Dependent on ECB Funding
summary: Ireland's banks are still heavily dependent upon European Central Bank funding, even as figures released Friday showed they borrowed less last month.

headline: Telecom Operators Report Damaged Undersea Cables
summary: The earthquake in Japan damaged undersea cables on and could affect connectivity of calls made between China and Japan. China Unicom and Chunghwa Teleco of Taiwan reported damage.

headline: Ayala Net Jumps 37%
summary: Ayalasaid robust economic growth helped boost its 2010 net profit by 37%, prompting the Philippines' oldest conglomerate to plan a record level of capital expenditure this year.

headline: Insurers Pull Down European Stocks
summary: European stocks closed at their lowest level this year on Friday, after insurance stocks tumbled on the strongest earthquake to hit Japan in more than 100 years.

headline: Azerbaijan Protestors Fail to Gain Clout
summary: Police in the oil rich Caucasus nation Azerbaijan detained more than 40 people on Friday who attempted to repeat Egypt's antigovernment uprising, even as the European Union expressed "concern" over the government's heavy handed tactics.

headline: European Reinsurers Shares Slide
summary: Shares of european reinsurers fell sharply Friday on the prospect of big losses from the powerful earthquake that struck Japan, causing damage in Tokyo and sending a tsunami toward the country's northeastern coast and Pacific Rim countries.

headline: Gates Pays Surprise Visit to Bahrain
summary: U.S. Secretary of Defense Robert Gates made a surprise stop in Bahrain on Friday, landing on a day of huge political protests against a regime that has been a longtime U.S. ally.

headline: When Girl Scout Cookies Create Turmoil
summary: Some small businesses make it a rule to prevent sales of Thin Mints or Samoas in the workplace. Others welcome the activity - as long as scouts themselves make the sale.

headline: Canada Is Little Affected by Tsunami
summary: The initial effects from the tsunami triggered by a massive earthquake that hit Japan are expected to hit the coast of the Canadian province of British Columbia early Friday, according to an advisory released through the office of Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper.

headline: Japan Looks at How to Fund Reconstruction
summary: The Bank of Japan, government officials and usually warring politicians promised to do what they can to figure out how to pay for the reconstruction work and the economic fallout from Friday's earthquake.

headline: The Dow's Plunge: Should You Be Worried?
summary: Was Thursday just a small but passing cloud on an otherwise sunny horizon? Or was it something more ominous? Here are 10 reasons to be concerned.

headline: Sberbank to Buy Troika Dialog
summary: Sberbank, Russia's biggest bank, will purchase the country's oldest investment bank, Troika Dialog, for $1 billion in cash and a possible future payment that depends on the investment bank's results.

headline: Biden Pledges Aid, Support to Moldova
summary: U.S. Vice President Joe Biden, fresh off a tough speech on Russian human rights, sided firmly with this country's Europe-minded leader over opponents pressing for closer ties to Moscow.

headline: Air Canada Threatens to Pull NHL Sponsorship
summary: Air Canada has threatened to withdraw its NHL sponsorship unless the league does more to crack down on violence.

headline: India Shares Down on Japan Quake
summary: Indian shares fell for a second consecutive session Friday after a powerful earthquake jolted Japan's northern coast and triggered a tsunami, sparking selloffs in markets across Asia and Europe.

headline: Ferragamo Focuses on Remaining Independent
summary: Salvatore Ferragamo has the ability to survive as an independent Italian firm despite pressures prompting the group's peers to pair up with rivals, the company's chief executive said.

headline: Gates Warns on Afghan Drawdown
summary: U.S. Secretary of Defense Robert Gates delivered a blunt message Friday to allies in Afghanistan: Don't rush for the exits.

headline: Your Tsunami Photos
summary: Were you there when the earthquake hit Japan, or were you among those evacuated along Pacific coasts? Email us your photos of the damage, at.

headline: Airlines Cancel, Divert Flights Following Japan Quake
summary: Airlines around the world cancelled, delayed or diverted hundreds of flights, grounding thousands of passengers after the massive earthquake affected airports in Japan.

headline: Crude's Post-Quake Fall Likely to Be Short-Lived
summary: Crude-oil prices fell while oil-products markets strengthened following news of a severe quake and tsunami in Japan. The extent of the impact on oil infrastructure remained unclear, traders said.

headline: German Parliament Head Criticizes Merkel on Euro-Zone Pact
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel failed to inform lawmakers sufficiently when coming up with a proposal for a "competitiveness pact" to reform the euro zone, the president of the German parliament said in a letter to the chancellor.

headline: Market Tumble Puts Investors on Alert for Correction
summary: As the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 fell below key levels Thursday, investors began to worry: Could this be the start of the much-anticipated correction?

headline: Dow Below 12000 on Mideast Worries
summary: Financial markets around the globe were shaken Thursday by escalating turmoil in the Middle East, fresh reminders that Europe's debt crisis remains unresolved and surprisingly downbeat economic news out of China.

headline: Wells CEO Hints at Brokerage Acquisition
summary: Wells Fargo's CEO John Stumpf said he would like to boost the bank's share of the nation's wealth—possibly by acquisition. The bank's new finance chief, Timothy Sloan, also said the Fed is on track to advise banks on dividend increases by March 21.

headline: Japan's Nikkei Falls 1.7%
summary: Stocks in Tokyo fell sharply after a powerful earthquake rocked Japan, and stocks in some other Asian markets also extended losses amid fears of damage to the Japanese economy.

headline: Clearwire CEO Resigns In Shake-Up
summary: Clearwire said its CEO, Bill Morrow, and two other senior executives resigned in a management shake-up of the high-speed wireless service provider.

headline: Sony Executive Faces New Game
summary: Sony's tapping of Kazuo Hirai as CEO front-runner suggests an accelerated push to closely couple its electronics hardware with its portfolio of movies, TV shows, videogames and music.

headline: Hutchison Port IPO Gets Middling Price
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust set an indicative price of $1.01 per unit for its giant Singapore IPO, a level well below the top end of its initial indicative range.

headline: Japanese Yields Drop on Quake
summary: Japanese bond yields tumbled Friday as investors sought safe-haven assets after a strong earthquake shook Japan from the north to the Tokyo metropolitan area just before markets closed.

headline: Neiman Marcus's Profit Jumps
summary: Neiman Marcus reported a sharp rise in quarterly as sales and margins improved amid a rebound in the high-end retail market.

headline: Portugal Vows More Budget Cuts
summary: Portugal's government pledged a fresh batch of measures to reduce spending and boost revenue, amid growing fears that its high borrowing costs may soon force it to seek a bailout.

headline: AIG Offers to Buy Back Subprime Bonds
summary: AIG, once hobbled by its bets on the mortgage market, is trying to buy back a large portfolio of subprime mortgage bonds from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which acquired the securities as part of the insurer's massive bailout in 2008.

headline: India vs. the Netherlands
summary: Some snapshots of the Group B World Cup match between India and the Netherlands at Feroz Shah Kotla in New Delhi, Wednesday.

headline: West Indies vs. Ireland
summary: Some snapshots of the World Cup Group B match between West Indies and Ireland.

headline: Mundra to Bid for Australia Coal Terminal Rights
summary: Mundra Port & Special Economic Zone has shown interest in acquiring the operating rights of a major coal export terminal in northern Australia, and expects to submit a formal bid by April 8, a senior executive said.

headline: India Iron Ore Prices Fall on Low China Demand
summary: Indian iron ore export prices have fallen by up to 50% in the past month due to low demand from main buyer China, two industry executives said. India usually exports nearly half of its iron ore production to China.

headline: India Industrial Output Up 3.7%
summary: India's industrial output grew 3.7% in January, compared with a 16.8% rise in the same month a year earlier, government data showed Friday.

headline: Quake Produces Flood of Tweets
summary: As communications networks in Japan went down after the earthquake struck on Friday afternoon, many people looking to contact loved ones and get updates turned to microblogging services.

headline: U.K. Producer Prices Rise at Fastest Rate in 2 Years
summary: U.K. producer prices accelerated at the fastest rate in two years in February as oil and food prices rose, adding to the inflationary pressures that could prompt the Bank of England to raise interest rates in coming months.

headline: Hungary Confident on Budget Plans
summary: A senior Hungarian finance official said he is confident that new government budget plans will boost the country's drooping credit ratings and revive investor confidence ahead of a planned bond offering later this year.

headline: Nikkei Falls 1.7%, TSE Unaffected
summary: Tokyo stocks fell sharply, as broad market weakness on the back of higher-than-expected China inflation data was exacerbated by the quake.

headline: ICVL Poised for Stake in Singapore's MEC Coal
summary: India's International Coal Ventures Private, a consortium of five state-run metals and energy companies, is close to buying a 24% stake in Singapore-based MEC Coal for around 9 billion rupees ($200 million).

headline: Missing Palestinian Found in Israeli Jail
summary: A prominent Palestinian engineer from the Gaza Strip turned up in an Israeli prison shortly after his disappearance from a train in Ukraine last month, according to a United Nations official and an Israeli legal defense group.

headline: Japan Opening to Oil Exploration
summary: The Japanese government said it plans to offer a range of onshore and offshore blocks for oil and gas production, and that it is amending its mining law to allow this.

headline: German Consumer Prices Rise 2.1%
summary: Consumer-price inflation in Germany showed the highest reading in more than two years in February as energy prices continued to rise, the Federal Statistics Office said.

headline: Ferrari's Big Four
summary: Italy's Ferrari SpA said Thursday it will start selling its sports cars in India from this spring. Some snapshots.

headline: China's Trade Heft Tests Global Partners
summary: China is now the top trading partner for six G-20 economies and its rise as a trading power is felt in nearly every corner of the globe—in ways not always welcome.

headline: Where to Invest Your Money Now
summary: Consider buying stock mutual funds because they can provide better returns than fixed deposits over the next three to five years, says Shefali Anand, India personal finance writer.

headline: China Consumer Prices Rise 4.9%
summary: China said inflation remained high last month, fueling further doubt about the government's ability to tackle what officials have called their main economic priority this year.

headline: Vietnam Fights Black-Market Dollars
summary: Vietnam is cracking down on unauthorized trading in U.S. dollars in an effort to bolster the country's dwindling foreign reserves and restore confidence in the local currency, the latest attempt to bring some stability to the economy.

headline: Celebs Gather in Midtown to Roast Trump
summary: What does it take to convince Donald Trump to allow his sex life, business failures, presidential aspirations and, of course, his distinctive head mop to be mocked in the crudest possible terms for two solid hours? Apparently $2 million.

headline: Jamie Whyte: Cameron's Comedy Economics
summary: Britain's prime minister is sounding more like an 18th-century mercantilist than a modern policy maker.

headline: Get the Lead Out, Mr. President
summary: Nutty test standards give Obama a real chance to help business.

headline: A Colorful Past in Newport
summary: This Cotswold-style house sits on land that served as a private hunting ground in the late 1800s for Oliver Hazard Perry Belmont (of Belmont Park racetrack) and his friend Cornelius Vanderbilt.

headline: Online Fashion's Achilles' Heels
summary: Online-fashion retailers' valuations are reminiscent of the dot-com bubble, and it wouldn't take much to throw a stiletto into investor expectations.

headline: Shopaholics' Crash Pads
summary: Shopaholics' crash pads in New York, Beverly Hills, Calif., and Boston.

headline: City, State Spar Over Homeless Aid Cuts
summary: New York City said it will stop next week moving families from homeless shelters to apartments as a result of a proposed cut in state aid.

headline: These Parents Are Involved, but They're Getting Nowhere
summary: The question is whether the rejection of the Compton parents' petition to reform a failing elementary school under the state's "parent trigger" law represents a major defeat or a mere setback ("Crushing Hopes in Compton," Review & Outlook, March 2).

headline: France, U.S. Reach Out to Rebels
summary: The U.S. and France dealt new diplomatic blows to Col. Moammar Gadhafi's government Thursday, but the international community stepped gingerly toward taking military action against the Libyan strongman.

headline: Rhyme, No Reason
summary: Homework for shareholders: Find a rhyme and Wells's profits will climb. Maybe.

headline: Cogan, Hubbard and Kessler: ObamaCare and the Truth About 'Cost Shifting'
summary: There's simply no evidence to support the claim that the insured bear the costs of caring for the uninsured.

headline: Investors Get Picky With Corporate Bonds
summary: Corporate-bond issuance slowed to a trickle amid signs investors are pushing back against some terms offered by borrowers.

headline: Sonoma Peach Retreat -- Photos
summary: Intended as a weekend getaway, a 6 1/2-acre property with a 1950s-era house became the site of a peach business for the owners.

headline: We're Not Breaking Windows
summary: OSHA's administrator defends Obama regulations.

headline: Business Watch
summary: Here is a selection of business news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Court Suspends Santander CEO
summary: Spain's Supreme Court sentenced Banco Santander CEO Alfredo Sáenz to three months of imprisonment and suspended him from banking for the same period for making false accusations in a case dating back to 1994.

headline: A Peach of a Place
summary: A big city couple build a burgeoning second career out of an old Sonoma farm.

headline: Daniel Hannan: A European's Warning to America
summary: Americans deserve better than the European model that Obama is trying to implement.

headline: Nevada Eyes Legalizing Web Poker
summary: A Nevada legislator proposed a bill that would direct regulators to legalize online poker, adding Nevada to a growing number of states considering Internet gambling bills.

headline: GM CFO Liddell Resigns
summary: General Motors said finance chief Chris Liddell, who often clashed with other executives at the auto maker but won plaudits for rebuilding its troubled finance department, is leaving after 14 months on the job.

headline: Three-Week Bill on Spending Seen
summary: House Republicans plan to unveil another short-term measure Friday to keep the government operating while they negotiate over this year's federal budget with Democrats and the White House.

headline: Asli Aydintasbas: Turkey's Press Crackdown Continues
summary: Journalists are being jailed for an alleged coup plot and we all assume our phones are tapped.

headline: A True Adventure at Sea and on Shore
summary: In 1835, young Richard Henry Dana Jr. set sail from Boston, bound for California via Cape Horn. In his classic memoir, "Two Years Before the Mast," Dana remembers the raging storms, the California coast and losing comrades to the sea—it remains one of the finest books ever written on the subject.

headline: St. John's Falls Short
summary: The Red Storm fell to Syracuse, 79-73, in a tightly contested Big East Tournament quarterfinal.

headline: Scots, English Face Off in Six Nations
summary: Scotland travels to England in rugby's Six Nations tournament in a game that marks the centenary of the first meeting between these two at à, the home of English rugby.

headline: Sheen Sues Warner Bros.
summary: Charlie Sheen filed a $100 million lawsuit against Warner Bros. and Chuck Lorre, co-creator of "Two and a Half Men," over his termination from the hit TV show.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide

headline: Strassel: Ready for Unionized Airport Security?
summary: As payback for union support, the Obama administration greases the wheels for the largest federal organizing effort in history.

headline: Glaxo Sees Research Payoff
summary: Glaxo hopes the FDA's approval of a new lupus treatment discovered by Human Genome Sciences is just the first in a string of products springing from the collaboration.

headline: Gadhafi Forces Escalate Attacks
summary: Forces loyal to Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi pounded a rebel-held oil-refinery city Thursday from the ground and air, in what appeared to be an escalation of the government offensive against opposition fighters in the east.

headline: Jury Hears Galleon Wiretaps
summary: The U.S. government played two of its best cards in the insider-trading trial of Galleon's Raj Rajaratnam: testimony from its star witness and secretly taped telephone recordings of Rajaratnam allegedly receiving inside information.

headline: Walker's Late Shot Lifts UConn to Win
summary: Bronx-born Kemba Walker  used a crossover dribble and shoulder roll to shuck his defender right to the ground, then stepped back and swished the winning basket at the buzzer to power ninth-seeded UConn past top-seeded Pitt, 76-74.

headline: Egypt Prisoner Release Sets Off Alarms
summary: Egyptian protesters are pressing for the release or civilian retrial of the country's remaining political prisoners—including, to the alarm of U.S. officials, militants involved in scores of terror attacks.

headline: Connecticut's Malloy Facing a Tough Sell
summary: This week the governor continues a 17-stop town-hall tour across the state to assuage residents' fears over his call for "shared sacrifice" to plug the state's estimated $3.3 billion budget deficit.

headline: TV on DVD
summary: Next week's releases of past television series.

headline: Cumulus Media to Buy Citadel
summary: Cumulus agreed to acquire rival radio broadcaster Citadel Broadcasting in a $2.5 billion cash-and-stock deal, following months of exclusive talks.

headline: Her Master's Voice From the Other Side
summary: In "Ghost-Writer," a secretary continues to hear from her employer and transcribe his novels after he's dead. It's a tale pulled from the real life of author Henry James, at the Florida Stage in West Palm Beach.

headline: USDA Edges Up Grain-Supply Outlook
summary: U.S. government forecasters eased concerns over low grain supplies, slightly increasing estimates for global supplies of corn, wheat and soybeans, while leaving projected domestic supplies mostly unchanged.

headline: Painting's Changing Landscapes
summary: "Natural and Ideal: Landscape Painting in Rome 1600-1650" at the Grand Palais in Paris offers ample evidence that landscape painting as a genre all its own developed very quickly, during the first half of that century.

headline: The Search for Aretha's Sound
summary: Before Aretha Franklin became the Queen of Soul, she was a budding Princess of Pop.

headline: Some Wish They Were Back in the U.S.S.R.
summary: No country in the world recognizes Transnistria as a sovereign state. But that hasn't stopped authorities in this breakaway part of Moldova from adopting the trappings of Soviet-style nationhood.

headline: Nassau Crime Lab Probe Widens
summary: The Nassau County district attorney says she plans to expand a probe into the area's crime lab by retesting scores of drunk-driving cases, a step that comes days after a judge threw out a DWI conviction because of questions about the lab's drug-testing problems.

headline: Paul Wolfowitz: The Case for Backing Libya's Rebels
summary: The U.S. has a strategic and moral interest in helping Libyans fight for themselves, and in preventing Gadhafi and his sons from restoring their reign of fear.

headline: Blockbuster Avoids Liquidation
summary: Blockbuster won a judge's blessing to sell itself—and avoid liquidation—after lawyers hammered out a new deal to give better terms to movie studios.

headline: Covert Maneuvers Grease California Budget Talks
summary: California's top lawmakers have publicly distanced themselves from budget talks between five Republican senators and Democratic Gov. Jerry Brown. Behind the scenes, they have played key roles moving them along, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: It's In the Bag
summary: A few years ago, columnist Tina Gaudoin overambitiously predicted the death of the "It Bag." In fact, a fate far more constructive has befallen what is the most meaningful and practical of women's fashion items.

headline: Amazon Takes Action in Illinois
summary: Amazon.com is ending its relationship with marketing affiliates in Illinois because of a new law aimed at making the online retailer collect sales tax in the state.

headline: HBO Feels Some Heat
summary: HBO, home of popular TV shows including "Big Love" and "True Blood," is under pressure to recoup lost subscribers and fend off skepticism about its competitive position in a rapidly shifting media landscape.

headline: A Director Goes to the Mat
summary: For his latest film, "Win Win," Tom McCarthy had an unlikely mix of inspirations: difficult economic times—and the pressures of high-school wrestling.

headline: From 'Alice' to 'Jane'
summary: This weekend, the 21-year-old Australian actress Mia Wasikowska tackles yet another 19th-century literary heroine: Charlotte Brontë's Jane Eyre in Focus Features's new adaptation of the novel.

headline: LinkedIn Adds News Service
summary: LinkedIn introduced a news service for users of its professional network as part of its effort to broaden the website's use as it approaches an initial public offering.

headline: Downtown Art Star Still Rising
summary: Yuka Honda has taken an accidental path from lost New Yorker to adventurous musician.

headline: Dalai Lama Cedes Role
summary: The Dalai Lama announced plans to formally step down as political leader of the India-based Tibetan government-in-exile.

headline: Bergen Street Attracts Colorful Mix of Shops
summary: Landlords Michael and Matthew Pinkchik culled hundreds of proposals to come up with a mix of shops they selected for Bergen Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

headline: Suspected Pirates Indicted in Killings
summary: A federal grand jury has indicted 13 suspected pirates from Somalia and one from Yemen in the February hijacking of a yacht that left four Americans dead.

headline: E-Book Lending Takes Off
summary: New online clubs that let readers share have drawbacks but worry publishers.

headline: Want to See Jeter Reach 3,000? Get Your Tickets Now
summary: Derek Jeter needs just 74 hits to become the 28th member of the vaunted 3,000-hit club, which should make Yankee games in mid-June the city's hottest tickets.

headline: Japan Pension Fund Seeks Risk
summary: The chief investment officer of Japan's Pension Fund Association, which oversees $130 billion in corporate retirement funds, says to boost returns the fund needs to take on more risk, in part by building up private-equity investments.

headline: Meet St. Vincent's Replacement
summary: St. Vincent's Catholic Medical Centers of New York, which filed for bankruptcy and closed last April, will end up as part luxury housing complex and part emergency-medicine center under a deal announced Thursday.

headline: Threat of Trial Keeps Gadhafi Fighting
summary: Now that the International Criminal Court has opened an investigation into Col. Moammar Gadhafi, the threat of a trial may well be a reason why the Libyan leader has chosen to battle his own people instead of seeking exile.

headline: AOL Chops 20% From Work Force
summary: AOL will slash its workforce 20%, eliminating 950 jobs in the U.S. and India as it struggles to resurrect its business.

headline: Citadel's Ken Griffin Buys in Hawaii
summary: Ken Griffin, the chief executive of Citadel in Chicago, has bought an oceanfront home at the Four Seasons' Hualalai resort in Hawaii for just under $17 million.

headline: Credit Suisse to Pay $70 Million to Settle Suit
summary: Credit Suisse has agreed to pay $70 million to settle a securities class-action lawsuit filed by investors alleging that the bank misled investors about its mortgage exposure during a roughly one-year period that began in 2007.
